Wayne Haskett, from Cannock, houses his collection of medieval items which he has accumulated over the past  years in his realistic medieval-themed man cave in his garden. His obsession with medieval times started when he was a child and has grown over the years. Wayne even had a medieval and Game of Thrones themed wedding when he married his we, Claire, last year, for which he wore full knights outfits. Wayne says that when people walk into his man cave, which cost £, to complete, their jaws drop to the ground and they say it is like going back in time. The decision to build the themed shed began in lockdown last year, he said. He had around  items of medieval memorabilia that he had spent the past  years collecting, which had previously been displayed around the house.  My we, Claire, , also has an interest in the medieval times but she wasnapost so keen on all the stuff being around the house as she feels like itaposs her domain, ” Wayne said. So when I mentioned the idea of the themed man cave, she was very supportive because it meant all of the items would get moved out of the house and be used to decorate the Yawning Portal.” He predominantly built the structure himself, he said, with a bit of help from friends and family along the way. In total, it took around five months and cost around £k to complete. It has a fireplace with an original cast iron fire backplate to add to the middle ages theme, a make-believe well and an eight-seater table,” he said. And the walls are just plastered with my collections such as my French medieval tapestry, ornamental swords, old books and tankards to give it the medieval fantasy look I want.  Just outside the front of it, I have also created a Viking set up with a themed table and chairs where we like to have BBQs.” Itaposs all very realistic,” he added. Wayne’s love for medieval times has been growing since he was a child. He loved history lessons at school and playing games such as dungeons and dragons with his friends. In his twenties, he then started to collect historical items that were related to the middle ages and even went on to have a medieval-themed wedding. After meeting his we seven years ago, Wayne says that Claire had a little interest in medieval times which grew thanks to him and his passion.  The care worker said his Game of Thrones themed wedding last year had been “fantastic”, and insisted Claire had loved it as much as he did. I had all my ushers in full medieval attire and I was dressed as a knight. I was walking around in chain mail all day which was very heavy,” he said. Claireaposs dress also matched the theme. It was so good and everything looked great.” Wayne said his passion for medieval times had got him into “so many” enjoyable hobbies, including longbow shooting, Comicon events and martial arts.  Iaposm really happy with the medieval man cave that I created as it pays homage to medieval fantasy and Game of Thrones,” he said. I have collected all my pieces from ious places, such as antique fairs, emporiums and by searching online.” Having a place to go, to admire all of his items was great, Wayne said. “I like going down at night time with the fire flickering because I can really relax and take it all in. And the top choice for both girls and boys remains unchanged this year - with Olivia and Oliver taking first preference among parents in England and Wales for the eighth year in a row. However, it seems these names tend to be most popular with older parents, as the data also showed that younger parents favoured shorter names like Leo and Theo for boys and Ava and Ivy for girls. Archie jumped into the top  boysapos names for the first time, driven by younger mothers as well as the obvious royal link, while on the girlsapos side, Ivy rose to sixth place. aposlooked like Sloth from The Gooniesapos after suffering a horror reaction to an eyebrow tint. Shocking photos show how Emily Priceaposs face ballooned and her her forehead aposcurled overapos into her eyes after applying the popular beauty treatment. Emily, , from Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales, said she was left with red and crusty-looking brows after a trip to the salon on September . The mum-of-one thought she wouldnapost need a patch test as she previously used the product routinely - though hadnapost since the pandemic outbreak. She was initially happy with the results, but claims her eyebrows started to tingle an hour after having them done and it felt like a aposhot pokerapos on her skin. But when Emily awoke unable to open her eyes properly she became concerned. She was horried when her startled husband leapt out of bed clutching a mirror so she could see her swollen, weeping face. Emily rang her GPaposs surgery but was forced to simply describe her symptoms over the phone as she couldnapost get a face-to-face appointment due to Covid. With her face continuing to balloon over the coming days, Emily went to AE where stunned staff prescribed her with powerful antibiotics to tackle the infection. Emily fears her new allergic reaction could be a result of having had the Covid vaccine, after reading about links made between people having had Covid or having the vaccine and experiencing new allergies, however there is nothing to prove that. And Emily, who is double-jabbed with the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, still remains a staunch advocate of getting the vaccine.  Emily, whoaposs never experienced allergic reactions in the past, watched in horror as her scabby eyebrows dropped off in patches - forcing her to colour them in with an eyebrow pencil. Now healed, writer Emily is now speaking out about her ordeal to ensure no-one goes through what she has and is urging people to always carry out patch tests, eventhey have previously not had an allergy.Whether youaposre an actual mummy or just the sort made of bandages, Halloween will be a big deal in your house. My husband was next to me, he turned the light on and looked at me and he was like aposoh my god whataposs happened to your face apos.  He ran and got a mirror, I could barely even see myself because my eyes were so swollen and I noticed that close, underneath the eyebrows, it had gone yellow. Days later I ended up going into hospital because it got worse. I looked like Sloth from The Goonies. An hour after having the beauty treatment Emily started to experience a tingling sensation and the following day she woke up to discover her face had ballooned. Worried at how it would develop, Emily managed to get a GP appointment over the phone on September th and was prescribed face wash, antihistamines and a steroid cream. But the medications did not help, and Emily took herself to Prince Charles Hospitalaposs AE department in Merthyr Tydfil on September  and was seen quickly by a skin specialist who started her on a strong course of antibiotics. She took a week-long course of antibiotics that cleared her skin but was horried when patches of eyebrow hair dropped out. Emily is sharing her experience to urge people to always get patch tested - claiming that although itaposs a apospainapos itaposs not worth being left aposlooking like a car crashapos. title: mum shares difference between two
story: Mum explains dference between  Covid battles - one before and one after jabAnouska Black, , said every breath felt like glass when she first contracted Covid-. The mum has been diagnosed with it again now, but said the jab has made all the dferenceMum Anouska Black said every breath felt like glass when she first got Covid but that changed when she was jabbed Image: Anouska BlackByApril Curtin:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum whose lung nearly collapsed when she was first struck by Covid- said the jab made all the dference when she contracted it a second time. Anouska Black, , from Co Down, Northern Ireland, said her body has been through trauma after she was originally diagnosed with the virus back in September . She said she completely randomly had an asthma attack and before she knew it she woke up in hospital with a lung that had nearly collapsed.The mum and step mum, from Magheralin, told Belfast Live : Thataposs actually how I found out I got Covid.The NI pageant queen was in and out of hospital for days before receiving a phone call to give her the dreaded news – she had the virus. She said: It kind of attacked my brain and my digestive system.  Anouska had no cough, temperature or loss of taste or smell. Instead, she suffered severe migraines, vomiting and diarrhoea – while sleeping around  hours each day. Three months after being diagnosed, the -year-old was still not getting better, and said every breath felt like glass. By December, she was back in hospital. Anouska said: Living it all again that second time, knowing youaposve got Covid, there was no messing about, it was really scary. I think my mum still has PTSD from it. Her anxiety went through the roof. The mum was put on tablets and given a full treatment plan. She has since gained multiple allergies, and in April, she was diagnosed with long Covid and post-Covid anxiety.  Speaking about her anxiety, she said: I thought I was fine but the doctor actually said my body basically is showing signs of anxiety. My whole breathing pattern has changed. You can see my body has been through trauma. Now, a year after catching Covid, Anouska has just tested positive again, despite being double jabbed since catching it the first time. I couldnapost believe it to be honest, she said.Can you catch Covid- twice It is possible to catch Covid twice, though it is unlikely. It’s not yet known how long Covid- vaccine protection lasts. Studies have shown that, for most people, catching the virus means you should be protected from getting it again for at least five months. But this depends on each inidual, and while it is unlikely, people have been known to catch Covid twice in a short space of time. Data indicates fully vaccinated people are much less likely to catch Covid- twice than those who are not. Earlier in October, Anouska broke out in an almighty red rash and said her teeth were chattering. She thought she was having an allergic reaction but has since been told could have been a symptom Covid and has tested positive.Her partner also has coronavirus and they have both also been diagnosed with mild pneumonia.Sharing a warning about Covid, Anouska said: When you canapost breathe, it is literally the scariest thing in the entire world. Itaposs like drowning with air. Do not hang about with this -you feel sick ring , ring your GP. Speaking about the vaccine, she said: I really believe it has saved me from going into hospital again. It hit me so hard last year. I was in hospital, I could have died. Thereaposs such a dference between the first time and the second time. And the only dference is, Iaposve had the vaccine. I would not have liked to have taken a chance the second time. She wanted to alert people to other symptoms of Covid, and said: Itaposs not just those three [symptoms]. Thereaposs no harm in staying up-to-date with the news. Anouska wants to encourage others to give people personal space and consider doing big shops again instead of taking unnecessary risks. She said: People have become so complacent. Le has to get back to normal, but just respect each other. Research from Electric Ride on Cars suggests the princess will far exceed her older and younger brothers in her fortunes, potentially being worth as much as £. billion, The Express reports. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters hereComparing other mini members of The Royal Family, Prince Harry and Meghanaposs son Archie is estimated to be worth £. million when he grows up. public, the royals are usually poised, professional and focused on the task at hand.But on the odd occasion, their frustrations can boil over and they are caught on camera saying or showing how they really feel.Just last week, the Queen was heard saying slamming world leaders as irritating for failing to commit to attending the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow next month.She said: We only know about people who are not coming and it’s really irritating when they talk, but they don’t do.” Here we look back at other times when royals from the Duchess of Cambridge to Prince Harry have let their displeasure at a situation be known...Queen scolds Prince William All cameras may have been on the Queen and her family as they took to the Buckingham Palace balcony for the traditional flyover after Trooping the Colour in .But that didnapost stop Her Majesty very publicly scolding her grandson Prince William for everyone to see.As Princess Charlotte, who was making her Trooping the Colour debut, was held by her mum Kate, Wills was in charge of looking after Prince George. The eldest Cambridge kid stood at the front looking over the thousands of people gathered below - and dad Wills crouched down to speak to him. However, granny clearly wasnapost impressed that the crowds would have been unable to see him, and appeared to berate her grandson by saying stand up William. Of course, the prince did as he was told and rose immediately, looking rather sheepish. Kate Middletonaposs epic eye roll  Kate has hardly put a foot wrong since joining the royal family after marrying Prince William in .In , while five months pregnant with Princess Charlotte, the couple travelled to New York, where Kate paid a visit to a childrenaposs centre to help them wrap Christmas presents.But after she stopped wrapping to chat to some of the volunteers, she was firmly told to keep wrapping.And in a rare candid moment, she light-heartedly rolled her eyes and did as she was told.Kate is said to have enjoyed the rest of her visit as she chatted happily with those at the centre.Princess Charlotteaposs meltdown  At only six years old, Princess Charlotte is probably just starting to learn how to navigate royal le.And in , when she was just two, she proved she was like any other toddler when she had a mini tantrum on the tarmac at Hamburg Airport.She had been visiting Germany and Poland with her parents and older brother Prince George when she and George had been given books as a gt.Her dad William took the book from her as they went to board a plane, but Charlotte clearly wasnapost ready to give it up and made her feelings clear.Cue some foot-stomping and collapsing to the floor in tears before mum Kate scooped her up in her arms - quickly avoiding a full-blown meltdown.Vexed Prince Harry  Itaposs known that Prince Harry is very protective of his we Meghan Markle and their children.So when a cameraman started getting too close to a pregnant Meghan on a visit to Morocco in  - he let his feelings be known.Harry was stood next to Meghan when he spotted the cameraman appearing to hit a child on the head with his equipment as he tried to get closer to the royal couple. The Duke quickly walked around the back of his we, presumably to not interrupt his host, before putting his hands on the lens and moving the man filming for Moroccan TV to one side. Prince Harry had a stern look on his face and instantly the cameraman backed off. The prince then put his hand on the girlaposs arm, askingshe was ok, before ing to listen to his host. title: valneva covid vaccine ditched uk
story: Valneva Covid vaccine ditched by UK has stronger immune response than AstraZenecaFrench pharmaceutical firm Valneva has today reported positive results from its Covid- trial after the UK Government scrapped a deal for Valnevas Covid- vaccineFrench pharmaceutical firm Valneva has today reported positive results from its Covid- trial Image: Stuart Vance ReachPlcByJane KirbySudip Kar-GuptaDanya Bazaraa:,  Oct | commentsThe Valneva Covid vaccine ditched by the UK has a stronger immune response than AstraZeneca, according to reports. French pharmaceutical firm Valneva has today reported positive results from its Covid- trial after the UK Government scrapped a deal for Valnevaaposs Covid- vaccine last month.The UK had about  million doses on order and Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited Valnevaaposs Scottish manufacturing site in Livingston in January.Valneva said its latest trial, on , participants aged  and older across  trial sites in Britain, showed the vaccine prompted a stronger immune response and fewer side-effects than AstraZenecaaposs shot. In new phase three results reported on Monday, the Valneva vaccine showed around % higher neutralising antibody titer levels compared with the vaccine from AstraZeneca in a head-to-head trial.  The company also said its vaccine - VLA - induced broad T-cell responses, a part of the immune system believed to be involved in long-term immunity. Adam Finn, professor of paediatrics at the University of Bristol and trial chief investigator, told a briefing that the figure for the vaccineaposs efficacy would come when the jab is used in the population. He said the Valneva jab is expected to be at least as effective as, and potentially more effective than the Oxford-AstraZeneca jab. But he said the efficacy of a vaccine is not proportional to the antibody titers that it generates, and there tended to be a threshold above which people were protected against infection or serious illness. Enough antibody is what you need and more antibody may not be any better, he added. The phase three trial recruited , people across  trial sites in the UK, including around , who took part in the comparison with AstraZeneca.  The number of Covid- cases was similar between those given AstraZeneca and those given Valneva, the firm said. It added that the complete absence of any severe Covid- cases may suggest that both vaccines used in the study prevented severe symptoms caused by circulating iants, mainly the Delta iant. Prof Finn said: The low levels of reactogenicity and high al antibody responses alongside broad T-cell responses seen with this adjuvanted inactivated whole-virus vaccine are both impressive and extremely encouraging. This is a much more traditional approach to vaccine manufacture than the vaccines so far deployed in the UK, Europe and North America, and these results suggest this vaccine candidate is on track to play an important role in overcoming the pandemic.  He told the briefing that it was unclear how the current vaccines would perform in the future and so more vaccines and more vaccine s could only be a good thing. Thomas Lingelbach, chief executive officer of Valneva, said: These results confirm the advantages often associated with inactivated whole-virus vaccines. We are committed to bringing our dferentiated vaccine candidate to licensure as quickly as possible and continue to believe that we will be able to make an important contribution to the global fight against the Covid- pandemic. Valneva started commercially manufacturing VLA at its Livingston site, which it describes as a globally qualied manufacturing site for viral vaccines, in January this year and will continue to do so. It expects to finalise its submission to the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyfor regulatory approval in November, with the hope the vaccine will be approved by the end of the year. Valneva hopes to initially get the jab approved for those aged  to  owing to the age range of people in the trial. The companyaposs site in Solna, Sweden, provides full fill and finish operations for VLA. title: wake up 3am cant stop
story: Why we wake up at am and cant stop worrying - yet by morning the fear has goneGreg Murray, a psychology researcher, and an expert in mood and sleeping explains why peoples worries are so much greater in the middle of the night than during the dayGreg Murray, a psychology researcher, explains why people worry more at night Image: Shared Content UnitByLiv ClarkeDaniel SmithTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWaking up in the middle of the night and having a panic attack about an event that by the morning suddenly seems unimportant is something we all do but why  We’ve all had one of those nights, where you wake up at around am and your mind slips into a spiral of negative thoughts.All your worries suddenly take on more importance in the middle of the night, leaving you worried and fretful and unable to get back to sleep, HullLive reports.Yet during the day these concerns no longer seem that serious - turns out you lost sleep over nothing. So, what’s going on  Greg Murray, a psychology researcher with expertise in mood, sleep and the circadian system , has explained why this happens.  Professor Murray says: “In a normal night’s sleep, our neurobiology reaches a turning point around  or am. “Core body temperature starts to rise, sleep drive is reducing , secretion of melatoninhas peaked, and levels of cortisolare increasing as the body prepares to launch us into the day.“Remarkably, all this activity happens independent of cues from the environment such as dawn light – nature decided long ago that sunrise and sunset are so important that they must be predicted .“We actually wake up many times each night, and light sleep is more common in the second half of the night. When sleep is going well for us, we are simply unaware of these awakenings. But add a bit of stress and there is a good chance that waking will become a fully self-aware state. “Not surprisingly, there is evidence the pandemic is a sleep-disturbing stressor. Soyou’re experiencing am wakings at the moment, you’re definitely not alone. “Stress also impacts sleep in insomnia, where people become hypervigilant about being awake. “Concerns about being awake when one “should” be asleep can cause the person to jolt themselves into anxious wakefulness whenever they go through a light sleep phase.  “If that sounds like you, be aware that insomnia responds well to psychological treatment with cognitive behavioural therapy. There’s also a strong link between sleep and depression, so it’s important to speak to your doctoryou have any concerns about your sleep.” “As a cognitive therapist, I sometimes joke the only thing good about am waking is that it gives us all a vivid example of catastrophising,” Professor Murray says. “Around this time in the sleep cycle, we’re at our lowest ebb physically and cognitively. From nature’s viewpoint, this is meant to be a time of physical and emotional recovery, so it’s understandable that our internal resources are low. “But we also lack other resources in the middle of the night – social connections, cultural assets, all the coping skills of an adult are unavailable at this time. With none of our human skills and capital, we are left alone in the dark with our thoughts. So the mind is partly right when it concludes the problems it’s generated are unsolvable – at am, most problems literally would be. “Once the sun’s up, we’re listening to the radio, chewing our Vegemite toast and pushing the cat off the bench, and our am problems are put in perspective. We can’t believe the solution of just ringing this person, postponing that thing, or checking such-and-such was overlooked in the wee hours.“The truth is, our mind isn’t really looking for a solution at am. We might think we are problem solving by mentally working over issues at this hour, but this isn’t really problem solving it’s problem solving’s evil twin – worry.“Worry is identying a problem, ruminating about the worst possible outcome and neglecting the resources we would bring to bear should the non-preferred outcome actually occur.” Professor Murray adds: “Have you noticed the am thoughts are very self-focused  In the quiet dark, it’s easy to slide unknowingly into a state of extreme egocentricity. Circling round the concept “I”, we can generate painful backwards-looking feelings like guilt or regret. Or turn our tired thoughts to the always uncertain future, generating baseless fears. “Buddhism has a strong position on this type of mental activity: the self is a fiction, and that fiction is the source of all distress. Many of us now practise Buddhist-informed mindfulness to manage stress in the daytime I use mindfulness to deal with am wakings. “I bring my attention to my senses, specically the sound of my breath. When I notice thoughts arising, I gently bring my attention back to the sound of breathing . “Sometimes this meditation works. Sometimes it doesn’t. If I’m still caught in negative thinking after  or  minutes, I follow the advice from cognitive behavioural therapy, and get up, turn on dim light and read. “This action may seem mundane, but at am it is powerfully compassionate, and can help draw you out of your unproductive thinking. “One last tip: It’s important to convince yourselfthat you want to avoid catastrophic thinking. For good reasons not to worry, you can’t go past the Stoic philosophers. “Waking and worrying at am is very understandable and very human. But in my opinion, not a great habit to get into.” Comment MORE ON Mental healthInsomniaTherapySleep" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: hooters backtracks new uniform policy
story: Hooters backtracks on new unorm policy after staff hit out at ‘underwear’ shortsThe restaurant chain brought in a new dress code that featured revealing skimpy shorts that has "upset" some employees Image: TikTokByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct | commentsHooters has been forced to backtrack on its controversial new unorm policy after complaints from staff members that said it was “x-rated” and “disturbing”. The restaurant chain, known for the tight-fitting unorms worn by its female staff, has now said it will allow employees to “choose” which unorm they wish to wear.In a statement to Insider, a spokesperson for Hooters said: “As we continue to listen and update the image of the Hooters Girls, we are clarying that they have the option to choose from traditional unorms or the new ones.They can determine which style of shorts best fits their body style and personal image. It followed its previous decision to replace already-short shorts for new skin-tight, bikini-cut bottoms, which some of its staff compared to underwear.  A series of viral TikTok videos shared by Hooters staff show employees speaking out against the shorts while others have threatened to quit as a result of the unorm change. “Oh look, a wedgie!” Hooters employee and medical student Kristen Songer, , said as she revealed the new shorts. “This is why all the Hooters girls are upset — because this is not what I agreed to wear a year ago when I was hired.”  In another video, one person compared the two shorts with the caption: “Love my job but don’t love wearing undies to work.” Another TikTok user said: “Soooo Hooters got new panties. I mean shorts.” The unorm change did receive positive feedback from some staff, one who said she was obsessed with the shorts while another asked Am I the only Hootie that loves the new shorts    “I’ve been making way more money with the new shorts,” a third said. Hooters has repeatedly come under fire for promoting the objectication of women through mandatory barely-there unorms, as well as staff beauty pageants and girl calendars.  The bar and restaurant chain launched in  with a unique selling point serving staff made up entirely of attractive, young women wearing orange hotpants and tight tops. Hooters of America, the franchisor and operator of Hooters restaurants, operates more than  franchise locations across  states and  countries. The company’s spokesperson added that the shorts were “the result of a collaboration with Hooters Girls and have been worn for months in several Texas markets with overwhelmingly positive feedback”. They said that Hooters appreciates the feedback, both positive and negative, regarding a more accommodating and inclusive image policy on tattoos, jewelry, nails, hairstyles as well as new unorm options — to include new top styles, shorts, and the addition of socks. The company said it plans to continue to work with employees and give them opportunities for providing input at every stage including future clothing items and accessories. Weaposre excited to see a national trend toward self-expression and inclusivity that bodes well for our marketplace, the spokesperson continued. We work continuously with our Hooters Girls to refresh and update the image of our brand ambassadors and to empower them to feel their best while at work. story: Mans internet search history made him No. suspect after girlfriend shot deadBrandon Theesfeld didnt want to be a father so he lured his student girlfriend Ally Kostial, , at the University of Mississippi, in Oxford, USA - who he believed to be pregnant - to her deathAlly Kostial was murdered by her boyfriend Brandon Theesfeld Image: FacebookByGail Shortland:,  Oct | comments Everyone who knew Alexandria Kostial loved that she was an eternal optimist. The -year-old always saw the good in people, which meant she treated everyone she met like a friend.But it also made her vulnerable and prone to being hurt.In , Alexandria – known as Ally and originally from St Louis, Missouri – was studying for a marketing degree at the University of Mississippi, in the city of Oxford, USA.She also taught fitness classes on campus and had started a golf club. In her freshman year in , she had met business student Brandon Theesfeld. Although they had never officially been a couple, they had dated on and off over the years. Ally’s friends knew that she had fallen for Theesfeld, but that he didn’t treat her very well and could be emotionally abusive. She would show them texts of him blowing hot and cold with his affections – saying he loved her one minute and then denying it the next.Students said Theesfeld was arrogant and liked to brag about his family’s wealth. Some even called him a misogynist. He liked to play the field and wasn’t committed to Ally. But Ally had some news for him.In April, she messaged Theesfeld to say she thought she might be pregnant.She sent him a picture of an inconclusive home pregnancy test and told him they needed to talk.Theesfeld started to ignore her messages and rumours started to circulate around campus.Ally’s friends heard she might be pregnant and other students heard that Theesfeld wasn’t very happy about it and wanted her to have an abortion.He thought a baby would ruin his le and his future.Ally tearfully told her friends she didn’t want an abortion.She wanted Theesfeld to meet her but their communication was purely electronic for the next three months. Ally had no clue just how badly the potential baby news had gone down. Theesfeld’s internet history showed he was researching abortion pills and services. And he travelled home to Dallas, Texas, and posted a photo on social media of a Glock pistol his dad had bought. The caption read, “Finally taking my baby back to Oxford.”On  July, he started to research gun silencers, ammunition and tactical face masks. Theesfeld also looked into how serial killer Ted Bundy had lured his victims to their deaths.Occasionally, he would agree to meet Ally but cancel at the last minute or not show up. On  July, Ally was out for the evening. Surveillance footage captured her leaving a nightclub in Oxford before midnight.She walked along and was looking on her phone. After ing home, she slipped out again without her roommates noticing.Then, at around .am the next day, a routine police patrol discovered a body in the remote area around Sardis Lake – a popular place for students to hang out, about  miles from downtown Oxford. The body was identied as Ally.She had been shot eight times in the stomach and her purse was found dumped a mile away. Straight away, Theesfeld was the prime suspect. He had messaged Ally the night before, asking her to tell him when she was leaving the bar.His truck was seen heading to her home around am, then towards the lake. Gunshots were heard at around .am at the lake and Theesfeld’s phone placed him leaving the area  minutes later.The bullets used to kill Ally were also the type for the gun he’d bragged about on social media.On  July, Theesfeld was arrested at a petrol station in Tennessee and charged with capital murder.He had blood on his clothing and his gun was found in his truck. It was matched to the bullets that killed Ally.Investigators determined that he had lured Ally to meet him and killed her to stop her having the baby.Tragically, an autopsy found Ally had not been pregnant after all. Had she really believed she was  We will never know.Theesfeld was facing a death sentence on the capital murder charge, so he made a plea deal.This August, Theesfeld, , pleaded guilty to first-degree murder. The prosecution said he had been unhappy believing that Ally was pregnant. They spoke about a letter he had written to his family, which was found after his arrest.“I’m not a good person. It is not your fault,” he wrote. “Something in me just doesn’t work. I’ve always had terrible thoughts. I know I’m going to get caught.”The prosecution said Theesfeld had tried to pressure Ally into getting an abortion and he had messaged suggesting that he had “felt becoming a father at this point in his le would ruin his le”. So he had taken his gun and lured Ally to her death, driving her to the lake and repeatedly shooting her.Afterwards, he had even looked up “Sardis, Mississippi news” – presumably to seeher body had been found. The defence agreed after a mental evaluation that Theesfeld was sane and competent to face trial.But they claimed drugs and alcohol influenced his behaviour.In September this year, Theesfeld faced sentencing. He apologised to Ally’s family but had no explanation for his terrible crime.“My actions have forever changed your lives and my family’s lives,” he said.“I wish I could take it all back but I can’t. There is no excuse for my actions. I hope one day that you will find it in your hearts to forgive me.”Ally’s heartbroken mum, Cindy, had written a letter that was read out in court, describing Ally as “bright, compassionate, sweet and hardworking”.It went on, “I wish I could have kept her away from this evil, callous, scheming, ungrateful, sinister and violent and corrupt monster. He had every opportunity to do good in the world but he chose to do evil. “Brandon, you belong in jail each day for the rest of your le for the heinous act you committed to such a sweet soul in Ally. Every time your cell door slams shut, may it be a reminder for what you did and the le you took from us.”Theesfeld was sentenced to le in prison and will be eligible for parole when he is . The case that had rocked the university two years earlier had finally come to an end. Ally’s family, who had worn pink in her memory, asked the community to always remember her – to honour her the way she’d been committed to them.They want the way she lived her le to be remembered, not the terrible way she died.Ally had always tried to take the positive out of every situation and now her distraught family are trying their best to do the same.Comment MORE ON University of MississippiPregnancyLe sentenceMurder trialSerial killersCrimeAbortionSurveillance" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i went toby carvery thats
story: I went to the Toby Carvery thats been branded the worst place to eat everThe Toby Carvery in Chadderton, Greater Manchester, had been dubbed the worst place to eat by one diner, so we decided to check it out for ourselvesThe restaurant has received mixed reviews online Image: MENByHana KellyEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsWhen it comes to roast dinners,you take snobbery out of the equation, Toby Carvery has got to be up there with the best of the best. You canapost really beat a chain which specialises in a good old Sunday dinner, can you  Or so you might think. According to TripAdvisor, many diners would disagree, with one particular branch of the restaurant chain taking a particular beating on the rating site.A Toby Carvery in Oldhamaposs Chadderton Park, in Greater Manchester, has been branded the worst place to eat ever, prompted the Manchester Evening Newsapos journalist Hana Kelly to go and check it out for herself.Food awful service even worse, worse place to eat ever, one review reads, while another diner wrote: Donapost have the Yorkshire puddings unless you want to lose a tooth or two. However, others tell of vastly dferent experiences as one reviewer writes: Amazing food, nice and warm, good service  good options. The server was fast and the food was cheap, but what did Hana think  Hereaposs her review.  What’s cooking  A delicious plate, full to bursting with fluffy yet crunchy roast potatoes, a Yorkshire pudding so crisp and rosy, it almost seems a shame to coat it in a thick, rich gravy. The veg should have a crunch, a sweet flavour to counteract the savoury deliciousness of the meat and the mix of trimmings, from stuffing to sauces should capture your senses before you’ve even taken a bite. At this Toby’s, the offering hit maybe % of this description. The Yorkshire pudding: truly faultless. It was golden with a crunch to match autumn leaves. The gravy: thick, flavourful, available in both meatysaurus and vegetarian options. The rest: Eh, acceptable. The turkey was dry. The kind of dry that meant when the carver was carving it, it cut not in slices but in small, frayed chunks like sawdust. The potatoes, in roasted form, were crisp on the outside and that’s that, no fluff, not much flavour. Meanwhile in mashed form, they were sweet and goopy. The vegetables were acceptable, certainly nothing worthy of review.  Are you being served  The enjoyment of post-Covid self service was definitely something missed by the patrons of the Chadderton Park Toby Carvery. One reviewer, who left one star on Tripadvisor, described the lack of self service during the pandemic as ‘not enjoyable at all’. They said: “The carvers throw it all on a plate on top of each other so it looks like a dogaposs dinner. But low and behold, self serve has ed, once your meat and Yorkshire are safely home on your plate, you can choose your own. A smiley waiter leads you to a table, takes your drink order and lets you know you may head for the carvery when ready. I sat for a few minutes contemplating what it meant to be ready before realising I just needed to get my dinner. However, this doesn’t mean there isn’t still confusion over the systems. One couple waited at their table for over  minutes wonderingthey’d been forgotten before flagging down a waiter and discovering they were meant to serve themselves. What’s the damage  If there’s one thing for certain, for a full roast the price is right. At a wonderfully affordable £., it is a good deal and great value for money. The verdict  As a Toby Carvery first timer, the meal was sadly disappointing. The staff were polite and relaxed, explaining the process, and serving drinks and the bill quickly. The atmosphere was warm and friendly, with laughter heard from many tables and tasty gravy smells wafting all throughout the pub. The queue at the carvery station was non-existent, meaning my food was still piping hot back at the table. There was ample parking, but the pothole ridden car park could have destroyed a caraposs suspension. But for a pub that sells itself on its roast, I’ve definitely cooked better.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. story: Man sparks debate after putting we on a budget to curb her spending spreesA pair of newlyweds have found themselves in an awkward disagreement over their joint finances after a husband put his we on a budget because of her spending spreesThe newlyweds got married earlier this year Image: GettyByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Oct | commentsMoney can be a dficult subject to talk about, especially for newlyweds who have suddenly found their lives - and finances - legally combined. But, itaposs fair to say that couples probably should think about discussing their separate and joint spending before making the commitment of tying the knot. In the not-too-distant past, it wasnapost uncommon for the man of the house to control the spending, given that in many circumstances, he would be the one to go out and earn the money while the woman of the house was considered the aposhomemakerapos. These days, however, in the majority of modern households, this is a far cry from reality.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. One man, who married his we earlier this year, has sparked an interesting debate online, after he revealed he was putting his we on a spending ban, after she spent the first seven months of their marriage on what he described as a spending spree.Sheaposs been spending hundreds at a time on clothes, accessories, makeup and all others that fall within that ilk, little trinkets for interior design, just spending all of the time, the -year-old man explained on Redditaposs Am I The A**hole forum.I make an okay living and the only reason we arenapost under water is because I donapost buy anything. After running up £ on a coat, I finally decided enough was enough. I built a spreadsheet, explained it to her, and wanted to handle things like adults. She acted like she was nodding off, struggling to stay away, she looked like a high school kid stuck in the most boring class in the school. Email us at yourmirror@mirrorThe man said he was expecting the conversation to turn into a fight as he thought it was perfectly fair, but his we argued that the budget didnapost benefit both of them and saw it was her husband dominating and constricting her. He then turned to Reddit to question whether he was in the wrong an he was met with ying responses. How on earth did you not talk about finances before you chose to get married  one Reddit user questioned, while another added: I donapost think lining out a budget is a bad thing. But it should include everything. Bills, living expenses and savings. Not just a budget for her. A third added: Everyone needs a budget, but this is something that should have been hammered out before you got married. Thereaposs a reason that money is a leading cause of orce. Personally, Iaposm a fan of yours, mine, and ours funds. Both partners get an equal monthly allowance to spend however they want, no questions asked. Anything  gets put into the aposoursapos fund and thataposs used for household costs. any household cost outside of normal bills over a certain amount has to be approved by both people. title: horrific real life squid game
story: Horric real-le Squid Game sees thousands of prisoners harvested for organs ALIVEWARNING: UPSETTING CONTENT. Tens of thousands of dissidents and political prisoners are reportedly harvested in China every year as part of a barbaric black market operation led by the Chinese governmentA Falun Gong follower displays torture methods they claim Chinese authorities used against their members in China Image: ReutersByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsCalled to a remote hillside on a hot summeraposs day, Dr Enver Tothi felt a chill down his spine as gunshots rang out across the fields. Walking his team over the summit, the medical expert was greeted by the sight of up to  men wearing prisonersapos unorms collapsed leless on the ground. Their heads had been blown off by military police who stood over twitching corpses - the job of Dr Tothi was to harvest fresh organs, which have become a valuable commodity on the Chinese black market. The horric scenes may sound eerily similarly to the side plot in Netflixaposs smash hit drama Squid Game, but the gruesome practice is all too real.Human rights groups in China claim the government is operating an organ-trafficking network that harvests as many as , dissidents and political prisoners every year.Hearts, kidneys, livers and even corneas are all removed on an industrial scale, campaigners say - while those involved have revealed grim secrets of witnessing the barbaric scenes first-hand. Organs aposharvestedapos like in Netflix hit Since its release last month, Squid Game has quickly become the most-viewed international show in Netflixaposs history. The creepy South Korean thriller sees desperate contestants battle it out in childhood-inspired games to win millions of pounds - the catch being thatthey fail, they die. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersWhile the far-fetched premise thankfully isnapost inspired by real le, a side plot sees workers for the aposgameapos dragging off injured participants to harvest their organs and sell them off. Just months before the showaposs release, UN human rights experts warned they were extremely alarmed by reports of alleged organ harvesting in real le. Minorities including followers of the religious movement Falun Gong, Uyghurs, Tibetans, Muslims and Christians are being targeted in detention in China, the reports claim. The UN experts say they have received credible information that detainees are being mysteriously subjected to blood tests and organ examinations such as ultrasound and x-rays - without consent. “Forced organ harvesting in China appears to be targeting specic ethnic, linguistic or religious minorities held in detention, often without being explained the reasons for arrest or given arrest warrants, at dferent locations,” they said. “We are deeply concerned by reports of discriminatory treatment of the prisoners or detainees based on their ethnicity and religion or belief. “According to the allegations received, the most common organs removed from the prisoners are reportedly hearts, kidneys, livers, corneas and, less commonly, parts of livers. This form of trafficking with a medical nature allegedly involves health sector professionals, including surgeons, anaesthetists and other medical specialists.”  China is facing a huge shortage of organs that can be used for transplants, but under controversial rules recipients can book surgeries for specic dates and locations. This doesnapost happen in other countriesapos systems, as surgeons cannot predict when a potential donor will die. Under Chinaaposs rules, the donoraposs organs will be sent to the most urgent patient on a waiting list who is within travelling distance. This has allowed the country to establish a horric aposkill to orderapos system, but despite widespread condemnation, Beijing has been able to cover it up by under-reporting transplant figures to the World Health Organisation.A recent statistical analysis of Chinaaposs current organ transplant system showed the numbers China has been putting out have been falsied, Susie Hughes, executive director of The International Coalition to End Transplant Abuse in China, told Daily Mail Australia.When you examine hospital revenues, bed utilisation rates and the number of surgical teams from the official Chinese data... the figure is more likely to be between , to , transplants per year. aposI became a robot... you carry out what you are programmed toapos China has persecuted a number of minority groups over the years, with thousands of Falun Gong detained as religious prisoners around the turn of the century. In , human rights lawyers began campaigning on the issue of organ harvesting, but  years later, little has been done to curb the sickening practice.  While the Falun Gong were once the target of the authorities, following its effective dissolution as a movement the Uighur - an ethnic group of Muslims now largely situated in the north-west of China - became the new scapegoat.Last year, the China Tribunal published a landmark  page report after  months of investigation into organ harvesting in the country. Dr Tothi - who now works as a London Uber driver - contributed to the enquiry, having been forced to remove a prisoners organs while working as a doctor in .I became a robot, the father-of-three told MirrorOnline. You carry out what you are programmed to do. When I cut through there was bleeding, which means the heart was still beating. I understood why. This man was shot to the right chest. They knocked him out but did not let him die immediately so I had time to remove the organs.  It was an easy and quick operation which took  to  minutes. Even less because it’s a destructive operation. The chief surgeon put the organs in a box and said aposnow you take your team back to hospital, and today nothing happenedapos. When Dr Tothi was made to carry out the brutal surgery, the Chinese Communist Party was concerned with the Falun Gong - a religious group that top brass considered to be a grave threat to their authority. The identity of the man he was forced to operate on, without anesthetic, remains a mystery to him. Prisoner x-rayed at horric concentration camp Tens of thousands of Falun Gong prisoners of conscience are thought to have been killed so that their organs could be sold in the lucrative black market.Among the lucky survivors was Jenner Zeng, who was saved from having her innards plundered by a chance admission to a prison guard. For  hours a day the mum-of-one was forced to stand in the sun and recite regulations at a prison camp in Beijing until she fainted, at which point a guard would shock her awake with an electric batton. Itaposs very sad, because we failed to stop them when they did this to Falun Gong, Ms Zeng toldof the state-run programme of forced organ harvesting. The western world funded this persecution by investing in China. Thenow has the power to expand this mass murder to Uighur and the people of Hong Kong. During her time in the camp Ms Zeng was taken to a medical facility where she had her eyes tested and her organs touched. She explained to the doctor that she had been infected with hepatitis C during a blood transfusion after giving birth, but had been cured of it in the process of practising Falun Gong. A month later she and several thousand inmates were taken in shackles in large buses with their windows blacked out to a hospital where they were x-rayed. At a smaller clinic back at the camp their blood was taken without explanation. It was only after her release that Ms Zeng learned that the authorities had been removing the organs of prisoners to be sold to wealthy and powerful people, from China and from overseas. Only at that stage, I realised what a narrow escape I had, she explained.  If I had not told the doctor I had had hepatitis C, I could have become a victim as well. From my first dayI had a strange feeling. Is this real  Have I been sent to the concentration camps in the history books  Could this be happening in the st century  We read about it in the history books but it doesnapost happen anymore. I had been transferred to the Nazi concentration camps. That kind of feeling haunted me for a long time. aposMy name is the butcher... itaposs like slaughtering pigsapos Also included in the  report is a transcript of a telephone call between an investigator and Zhu Jiabin, who admits to murdering and harvesting the organs of Gao Yixi in . Asked about the harvesting, Jiabin says: Sold them!’ After slaughtering and opening up the belly, you just carve out the organs and sell them. I only know to sell organs for money after organ harvesting. That is my principle... If you had guts to stand in front of me now I would live organ harvest you... My name is ‘the butcher’... I am called the butcher specialising in live organ harvesting... Itaposs nothing, just like slaughtering pigs. You come over to shave their hair first and then split open the belly. I would carve out whatever I need. After scooping the organs out, I would sell them.Last year, a group of doctors were found to have harvested the organs of car crash victims and then sold them for cash.Six people, including four doctors, were jailed in China having been caught up in the countryaposs thriving organ black market. It followed growing reports that the country was executing Muslim prisoners and taking their organs to treat patients dying of Covid-. Concerns were raised after Beijing boasted about a successful double transplant operation on a patient given just days to live. sweats# these are just a few of the symptoms of menopause. But did you know it can also cause problems with your bones Dr Atiyah Kamran, a consultant gynaecologist at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, says it#s important for women to look after their bone health to avoid osteoporosis.When women reach the age of menopause their oies stop producing high levels of hormones in the body.During the reproductive years, the hormone oestrogen helps to thicken the lining of the womb and stimulate the growth of egg follicles.But it#s also important for helping other parts of the body, contributing to our cognitive health, the cardiovascular system and how we absorb calcium.Oestrogen helps to protect our bones and, when levels of the hormone start declining in our s and s, it can lead to bone loss.A woman can lose up to % of her bone density during the five years following menopause which can lead to osteoporosis.Their bones become thinner causing them to fracture more easily.Today, on World Menopause Day, Dr Kamran has given some advice on how we can protect our bones.In the first instance, women should talk to their GPs to find outthey are likely to be suffering from menopause.Doctors can usually confirm it based on your symptoms butyou#re under the age of  a blood test can be taken to measure your hormone levels.Dr Kamran says it could be the case you#ll benefit from hormone replacement therapy , which will help replace lost oestrogen.#Not everyone needs HRT after menopause buta woman is suffering and her quality of le is suffering and she wants some relief from it then the options are available,# Dr Kamran said.#Every woman should have the right to ask.#Yes, there is. Dr Kamran says taking supplements and certain exercises can help.#Weight bearing exercises are considered good so walking, running, skipping – anything that would produce some weight on your joints,# she says.#It doesn’t have to be high intensity exercises.#We can also take supplements such as Vitamin B and Vitamin D. Living a healthy lestyle, reducing how much alcohol we drink and stopping smoking will also help.There#s also several natural remedies sold in health shops and on the internet such as red clover extract and black cohosh.They#re said to be effective because they contact plant-based compounds that mimic the action of the oestrogen hormone.But Dr Kamran warns we don#t know about the concentration of many of these products sold on the internet and they can react with other medications.#People with no other medical products can use these productsthey think that it helps them butthey use other medications it’s best to get advice from their doctor,# she said.#There are lots of things available on the internet but we do not knowthey improve the situation but they can cause harmunregulated amounts are used.#World Menopause Day is held every year to raise awareness of menopause and the support options available.If you#re looking for more information about menopause and the help you can receive visit the Menopause Matters website or The British Menopause Society.Here#s how you can be happy without chasing big achievements in your lePetition launched to get new hospital in Shetland Warning over infant virus doctors deem more concerning than Covid Man who hit #rock bottom# turns le around with boxingFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

insists he is not #burying my head in the sand# by retaining faith in his underperforming squad.The Dons have now failed to win in  games in all competitions and have lost the last five Premiership matches.With just two points from the last possible , Glass admits Aberdeen have hit rock bottom.Languishing ninth in the Premiership table and also having gone  games without a clean sheet, the pressure is on Glass to stop the rot.The Aberdeen boss continues to retain belief his squad can turn the season around # and he insists that is not blind faith.Glass said: #The frustrating thing is I feel I have been banging the same drum every week as it is the same story.#It feels like maybe people think I have my head buried in the sand a little bit.#But watching the team, I don’t think so.#It it turning.#I know how dficult it is going to be, but I back the players and I can see players that are capable of changing things.#Aberdeen now face a challenging run of games against the sides in title: thought for the week october 1 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInsects are tiny creatures, but they make a massive contribution in keeping our world in balance.They are responsible for the pollination of about  per cent of trees and bushes on the entire planet. Yet we often treat them in a dismissive way.Let#s think about some insects.Take the bluebottle. How often has it outwitted us with its amazing flight paths, ducking and ing to avoid our threatening gestures.While we have developed some of the most sophisticated flying machines the world has known, none can match the bluebottle in its agility.We have mentioned pollination. What insect is more important than the bee as it goes about its business from flower to flower ensuring that the plants will produce seed for another year and giving us honey as a product of its labours.How beautul too are its colours and the structure of its body – a remarkable little insect.Then there is the humble moth and its gravity-defying antics walking across ceilings. It has a very fragile body but in its short le can nevertheless act out its own acrobatic skill in an amazing performance.Or we may think of the spider and the beauty of its web, perhaps seen on a frosty winter morning. A true work of art woven with such delicacy.In the bible we read this: #Go watch the ants, you lazy person. Watch what they do and be wise. Ants have no commander, no leader or ruler, but they store up food in the summer and gather their supplies at harvest.# From this we can learn four things helpful to living: be diligent and hard-working have an #I can do it# attitude plan ahead remember teamwork is important.

title: star return to league action with victory
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star travelled to Ballerup, East Kilbride on Saturday October  to play their first league game since February  and ed home with three points after an excellent overall performance.The visitors started the game on the front foot and could have been ahead after three minutes when Fraser Talbot#s long range effort came crashing back off the bar.Star didn#t have long to wait before they opened the scoring, however, as Stuart MacLean reacted quickest to a slip in the Duncanrig defence to put his side ahead four minutes later.Talbot again came close to his first Red Star goal but was denied by the crossbar for the second time after finding space to shoot in the box.The lead was doubled soon after when Aaron Moore linked up well with Stuart MacLean on the right channel and powered his shot through the hands of the Duncanrig keeper.Star had several chances to make the game safe in the opening half hour with Craig Aitken and Andy Weir providing the ammunition from the wide areas but the final touch was slightly lacking.Coll McCallum was next to rattle the bar as his long-range effort took a bizzare bounce over the keeper#s head but the woodwork was once again kind to the hosts.Duncanrig pulled themselves back into the game with a rare attack which saw Star switch off and concede a disappointing goal as the midfielder was able to burst through the Star spine unchallenged to leave Ally Lewis with no chance.This stung Star back into action and the two-goal cushion was restored before the break when an excellent counter-attack saw Talbot lay a perfectly weighted pass into the path of Aitken, who finished with great composure to give Star a - lead at half time.Star looked to put the game to bed as quickly as possible in the second half and did so as Aaron Moore grabbed his second of the afternoon following a slip from the Duncanrig keeper.MacLean was next to double his tally as he proved too sharp for the Duncanrig defence and finished well from a tight angle to make the score - with half an hour to go.This gave manager Weir the chance to ring the changes, with Ryan Caskie coming on to replace Aaron Moore and helping himself to two goals of his own from close range to make the final score -.The only sour note was an injury to goal-scoring substitute Caskie which will rule him out of Star#s next game.Star look to make it back-to-back wins on Saturday October , again on their travels to Port Glasgow OBU.

story: A COMMUNITY run shop in Peeblesshire celebrated its official launch at the weekend.The Knot, in West Linton, has been up and running for a number of weeks.But it was officially opened on Saturdayat a special ceremony.The shop, which was formerly the Red Cross, offers books, secondhand clothes and homewares and has an additional gallery space for local artists to display and sell their work.:Aldi: Supermarket chain has plans to open new Peeblesshire locationAt the ceremony, Ian Reid, one of the members of the committee behind the shop, said: "Were so chuffed that so many people are here today."From am members of the community gathered at the Village Centre for homemade cakes before a procession from Raemartine Square to the shop on Main Street.A cake, which had been made by John Adam of Innerleithen, was decorated with a knot design by committee member Anne Suckling.And visitors to the village Jill and John Smart, who were on holiday in West Linton from Macclesfield were chosen to cut the cake.:Coronavirus: No new deaths in Borders for first time since August, figures showJoining the parade through the village was piper Glyn Morris who performed an original composition, Cut the Ribbon, created by resident Ben Gibbs.Councillor Heather Anderson, who represents Tweeddale West, shared on social media after the event: "It was just great to see the Knot officially opened [yesterday] with the splendid assistance of magnicent piper, Glyn Morris, who came all they way to West Linton to pipe us in."Many thanks to everyone who turned out in the rain and produced all those wonderful cakes in the Visitor Centre beforehand."It was a real pleasure to join you for the celebration.":Child, , hurt after being caught up in brawl near Borders primary schoolAnd untying the knot on the door to the shop were two of the young volunteers working with The Knot, Galina MacNeacail and Charlotte Wakelin-Grant.

title: knights-cgi-work-community-based-initiatives
story: AFTER A long period of no competitive rugby, Southern Knights are thrilled to have reached the  final of the FOSROC Super Rugby League and are particularly grateful to main sponsor global IT and business consulting services company CGI for their support over the past two years.Rob Chrystie, Head coach at the Southern Knights, said: ldquoThe Southern Knights management and players have really enjoyed theirto rugby since the end of July.CGI, our headline sponsor have shown unwavering support to the Southern Knights throughout extremely challenging times. We are exceptionally grateful for their continued support and determined to repay that commitment on the pitch whist working closely with them in the wider Borders community.ldquoDuring lockdown we were able to continue to offer rugby activities for the younger children, and during April we were able to support a new Try It Out campaign aimed at children that wouldnrsquot typically have access to rugby or sporting activities because of social or economic barriers. We feel very strongly that the ability to pay shouldnrsquot prevent access to sport.ldquoParents and carers were offered the option to pay what they could, or in some cases nothing at all. Over  boys and girls joined in the fun sessions at the Melrose pitches, and the majority registered to stay on until the end of the summer season. The lting of restrictions has allowed the Southern Knights to launch their buddy scheme aligning some of their semi-professional players to the younger players to help encourage and develop their skills and to inspire children to play to the best of their ability.ldquoThis inclusive ethos is shared by CGI and the award winning Inspire Learning Programme developed in partnership with Scottish Borders Council for pupils from primary four to sixth year in high school throughout the area.ldquoThis uses iPads and an array of other tools to support learning and aims to benefit all children and teachers by raising attainment, support equity and inclusion, and to work towards preparing young people for a digital future. We are keen to continue to support these initiatives in conjunction with CGI over the coming months and years.Dominic Taddei, Chair of Southern Knights Super Board said: ldquoWe are delighted to continue to work a further term with our headline sponsor CGI. Their support through very dficult times has been phenomenal and we look forward to working with them as we get ready to approach the finals day, and to now have the ability to offer a wider audience for FOSROC Super with the fantastic news that was released by Scottish Rugby on rd June  that every Super Sunday fixture has been televised live on free-to-air television by new broadcast partner, FreeSports. The FOSROC Super finals weekend will take place on the weekend of    October, and we look forward to showcasing CGI as our headline sponsor at the finals event.The continuing partnership between CGI and the Southern Knights is not only a relationship supporting sport in the Scottish Borders but also Southern Knights players and coaches are working closely with CGI on community-based initiatives in Borders schools, delivering motivational and inspirational videos for the pupils. CGI employees will also benefit from the relationship with the option to join in fitness sessions at the Greenyards and receiving motivational and leadership messages from the coaches.

title: hawick-man-drove-almost-four-times-legal-alcohol-limit
story: A BORDERS man who drove while almost four times the legal alcohol limit has been banned from the road for two years.Fty-six-year-old Allan Knox, of Hawicks Twirlees Terrace, pleaded guilty to the offence which happened in Mart Street, Hawick, on March .Joanne Waller, prosecuting, told Jedburgh Sherf Court that two witnesses saw the accused in Morrisons car park walking towards them in possession of a bottle of wine.They thought he appeared unsteady on his feet and askedhe was drunk or unwell but he replied he was depressed and was slurring his words.He then drove off in towards Linden Crescent and was followed by the witnesses.Ms Waller said Knox ed to the car park and was found by the police asleep in his vehicle with the keys in the ignition.He was arrested and taken to Hawick Police Station where he was cautioned and charged .Knox initially told officers he had not been driven but had earlier gone to Morrisons for a bottle of wine.He pleaded guilty to a charge of driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes ndash the legal limit being .Defence lawyer Ross Dow said his client had been struggling with depression following the end of his -year marriage.Sherf Valerie Johnston noted a previous conviction for drink driving and said as a result the minimumof ban was two years.In addition he was fined pound, reduced from pound due to the guilty plea, and a pound Victim Surcharge was imposed.

title: first-class-stamp-honours-first-class-player
story: BORDERS rugby legend Roy Laidlaw is to feature in a new set of stamps issued by the Royal Mail.The eight stamps in the set mark the th anniversary of the first international rugby match, staged between Scotland and England at Raeburn Place in Edinburgh in .Scrum-half Laidlaw, whose two first-half tries against Ireland at Lansdowne Road in Dublin, in , were instrumental in Scotland winning their first Triple Crown since , will feature.The former Jed-Forest star, who was capped -times for his country, recounted: ldquoI remember Ireland won the toss and decided to play against the wind in the first-half. I scored early off a lineout, then we got a penalty try at a scrum and then I got over in the corner off a scrum.ldquoI think Irsquod scored in the same corner a few years before playing for Scotland B.Due to injury, Laidlaw didnrsquotfor the second-half. ldquoBut we played some great rugby then. Keith Robertson scored a try and Peter Dods scored in the corner from a typically unselfish pass from Roger Baird.Laidlaw, who had captained Scotland and also toured New Zealand with the British  Irish Lions in , was in hospital as the celebrations at Scotlandrsquos - win continued into the night.He recovered to take his place against France at home a fortnight later when Scotland won their first Grand Slam in  years.He added: ldquoThat was just such an achievement. I mean, it was our first since . But while some of the boys were still partying, I was back at work the following Monday rewiring the public toilets in Jedburgh.ldquoI owed so much to my granny, Peggy Walker. She had introduced me to rugby when I was a kid. She saw the  Grand Slam in person the  Grand Slam in person and she watched the  Grand Slam on the telly. She lived to the grand old age of .ldquoSo, being on the stamp  Well, Irsquoll just say thanks to my granny Peggy, because it all wouldnrsquot have happened without her enthusiasm. title: abbotsford-cringletie-celebrate-scottish-tree-festival
story: TWO estatesin the Borders will be joining the dozens across the countryuntil December to celebrate the importance of trees to our lives and our landscape during the Scottish Tree Festival.The estates will be inviting visitors to explore some of the finest tree collections and to enjoy the spectacle as the canopy changes from green to gold and scarlet.At Cringletie near Peebles guests are being invited to walk amongst the woods and then enjoy afternoon tea in front of a blazing log fire while at Abbotsford near Melrose, the guided tours that are taking place during the Festival will include a chance to stroll amongst he woods that were planted by Sir Walter Scott himself.Dozens of gardens and estates, from Wester Ross to the Borders, are taking part in the Festival including Armadale Castle on Skye, Blair Atholl in Perthshire and Ardkinglas in Argyll where visitors can see some of Scotlands Champion trees - the biggest and broadest of their kind in the country.These and the many other events that will be taking part have been organised by Discover Scottish Gardens, which represents gardens and nurseries across the country.Joanna Macpherson, director, DSG, said: ldquoAgainst the backdrop of COP taking place in Glasgow, trees have never been more important and Scotland not only has a unique legacy of historic trees, but through careful conservation and replanting, this countryrsquos tree cover is increasing once again.ldquoThe Festival allows us to celebrate the place of trees in our lives, to enjoy their beauty and to explore how we can make more of them in our own gardens."

title: fasting-needed-see-full-benefit-calorie-restriction-mice---study
story: While long-term calorie restriction can provide health benefits, fasting may provide a boost to the effects, new research suggests.Studies have suggested restricting calories could result in lower weight, better blood sugar control and even longer lespans.But new research in mice indicates that reduced calorie intake alone is not enough, and fasting was essential for the animals to get the full benefit.The new findings lend support to preliminary evidence that fasting can boost health in people, scientists say.They add that the studies contribute to the growing picture of how health is controlled by when and what is eaten, and not just how much.Combined with eating less, fasting reduces frailty in old age and extends the lespan of mice, the study found.It also discovered that fasting alone can improve blood sugar and liver metabolism.Researchers found that mice that ate fewer calories but never fasted died younger than mice that ate as much as they wanted, suggesting that calorie restriction alone may be harmful.The research was led by University of WisconsinshyndashMadison School of Medicine and Public Health metabolism researcher Dudley Lamming, his graduate student Heidi Pak, colleagues at the university and other institutions.Professor Lamming said: ldquoThis overlap of treatment ndash both reducing calories and imposing a fast ndash was something that everybody saw, but it wasnrsquot always obvious that it had biological signicance.ldquoItrsquos only been in the past few years that people started getting interested in this issue.The researchers designed four dferent diets for mice to follow.One group ate as much as they wanted whenever they wanted. Another group ate a full amount but in a short period of time ndash giving them a long daily fast without reducing calories.The other two groups were given around % fewer calories either once a day or spread over the entire day.That meant some mice had a long daily fast while others ate the same reduced-calorie diet but never fasted, which dfered from most previous studies of calorie restriction.The results suggest that many of the benefits originally linked to calorie restriction alone all required fasting as well.Mice who ate fewer calories without fasting did not see these positive changes, according to the study published in Nature Metabolism.Fasting on its own, without reducing the amount of food eaten, was just as powerful as calorie restriction with fasting, the research suggests.Fasting alone was also enough to improve insulin sensitivity and to reprogramme metabolism to focus more on using fats as a source of energy.The livers of fasting mice also showed the hallmarks of healthier metabolism.However, the researchers did not study the effect of fasting alone on lespan or frailty as mice aged, but other studies have suggested that fasting can provide these benefits as well.While the mice that ate fewer calories without ever fasting did show some improved blood sugar control, they also died younger.Compared with mice who both ate less and fasted, these mice that only ate less died about eight months earlier on average.The team also measured frailty through metrics like grip strength and coat condition.Prof Lamming said: ldquoIn addition to their shorter lespans, these mice were worse in certain aspects of frailty, but better in others.ldquoSo, on balance their frailty didnrsquot change much, but they didnrsquot look as healthy.The primary studies were done in male mice but Prof Lammingrsquos lab also found similar metabolic effects of fasting in female mice.He added: ldquoIf fasting is the main driver of health, we should be studying drugs or diet interventions that mimic fasting rather than those that mimic fewer calories..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Fasting needed to see full benefit of calorie restriction in mice  u study

title: stirling-city-culture-scottish-city-makes-longlist---means
story: Stirling has been longlisted for the City of Culture , along with sevenother cities around the UK.It was one of three Scottish areas to apply, but the only one to make this years longlist in the biggest competition yet.The eight remaining citiesArmagh City,Bradford, County Durham,Cornwall, Derby, Southampton,Wrexham County Borough and Stirling will receive pound, ahead of the next stageof the competition.This money should be used to support each citys application, where they must show they can put "at the heart of their plans to recover from the impact of the pandemic".Heres everything you need to know aboutthe City of Culture competition and Stirlings chances...What is a City of Culture Every four years since , a city from somewhere in the UK has been selected as the city of culture.The idea was catalysed by Liverpools successas the European Capital of Culture in , with the first UK city of culture awarded to Derry Londonderry in .Kingston upon Hull won in  while Coventry is this years city of culture, an opportunity the West Midlands city has certainly not let go to waste.With a pound. million investment from the Government, Coventry has also attracted pound million from capital investment to support ious cultural projects.The awardhas the potential to regenerate cities, with Hull attractingmore than . million visits to over , events during its tenure.Culture secretary Oliver Dowden has said the award is good opportunity for cities to "build back better" from the pandemic.When will the shortlist be announced for the  City of Culture Those currently on the longlist will work witha  from the Departmentfor Digital, Culture, Media and Sport to finalise their bids, before ashortlist is announced in early .The final winner will then beconfirmed in May.What will the winner receive According to culture secretary Nadine Dorries, "Winning the UK City of Culture competition has a hugely positive impact on an area, driving investment, creating jobs, and highlighting that culture is for everyone, regardless of their background."This years focus is on levelling up access to culture across the country and making sure there is a legacy that continues for
